work.p: Words and phrases from this manuscript are similar to words and phrases used in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "The pride of the United States leaves the wealth and finesse of the cities and all returns of commerce and agriculture and all the magnitude of geography or shows of exterior victory to enjoy the breed of fullsized men or one fullsized man unconquerable and simple" (1855, pp. iii–iv).

The phrase "a breed of full-sized young men and women" closely echoes one that Whitman used in a section of his long manuscript poem "Pictures," which was first published posthumously in 1925. The first several lines of "Pictures" (not including the relevant section) were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880.

titleStmt.title: A remembrance
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Slightly altered versions of the phrase "a breed of full-sized young men and women" occur in both the preface to the first edition of Leaves of Grass (1855) and in the long manuscript poem "Pictures," the composition date of which is uncertain but which most likely dates from the late 1850s. Based on these similarities, then, the present manuscript could have been written at any time between the early 1850s, when Whitman was developing the ideas and language that produced the 1855 Leaves of Grass, and the several years afterward, as he experimented with turning the preface into poetry. The manuscript has been pasted down, so no image of the reverse is available.
